Stationarity

Stationarity is the foundation of time series analysis.

Strictly stationary

If the joint distribution of (rt1,...,rtk)(r_{t1}, ..., r_{tk})(rt1​,...,rtk​) is identical to that of (rt1t,...,rtkt)(r_{t1_t}, ..., r_{tk_t})(rt1t​​,...,rtkt​​), where kkk is an arbitrary positive integer and (t1,...,tk)(t_1, ..., t_k)(t1​,...,tk​) is a collection of k positive integers.

This is a really strong condition.

Weak stationary

{rt}\{r_t\}{rt​} is weak stationary if

E[rt]=μ,Cov(rt,rt−l)=γlE[r_t]=\mu, Cov(r_t, r_{t-l})=\gamma_lE[rt​]=μ,Cov(rt​,rt−l​)=γl​

In application, weak stationary enables one to make inference concerning future obeservations.

We can assume that the first two moment of a weak stationary series is finite. And if {rt}\{r_t\}{rt​} is normally distributed, weak stationary is equivalent to strict stationary.

Also, γl\gamma_lγl​ is called the lag-lll autocovariance of rtr_trt​. And we have

γ0=Var(rt),γ−l=γl\gamma_0=Var(r_t), \gamma_{-l}=\gamma_lγ0​=Var(rt​),γ−l​=γl​

Correlation and autocorrelation function (ACF)

Correlation efficient:

ρx,y=Cov(X,Y)Var(X)Var(Y)=E[(X−μx)(Y−μy)]E[(X−μx)2E[(Y−μy)2]\rho_{x,y}=\frac{Cov(X, Y)}{\sqrt{Var(X)Var(Y)}}=\frac{E[(X-\mu_x)(Y-\mu_y)]}{\sqrt{E[(X-\mu_x)^2E[(Y-\mu_y)^2]}}ρx,y​=Var(X)Var(Y)​Cov(X,Y)​=E[(X−μx​)2E[(Y−μy​)2]​E[(X−μx​)(Y−μy​)]​

And empirically, we can insert mean as the expectation in the formula.

Autocorrelation Function (ACF):

Consider a weak stationary series

ρl=Cov(rt,rt−l)Var(rt)Var(rt−l)=Cov(rt,rt−l)Var(rt)=γlγ0\rho_l=\frac{Cov(r_t, r_{t-l})}{\sqrt{Var(r_t)Var(r_{t-l})}}=\frac{Cov(r_t, r_{t-l})}{Var(r_t)}=\frac{\gamma_l}{\gamma_0}ρl​=Var(rt​)Var(rt−l​)​Cov(rt​,rt−l​)​=Var(rt​)Cov(rt​,rt−l​)​=γ0​γl​​

Then, the empirical estimation of ρ1^\hat{\rho_1}ρ1​^​.

ρ^l=∑t=l+1T(rt−rˉ)(rt−l−rˉ)∑t=1T(rt−rˉ)\hat{\rho}_l=\frac{\sum_{t=l+1}^T(r_t-\bar{r})(r_{t-l}-\bar{r})}{\sum_{t=1}^T(r_t-\bar{r})}ρ^​l​=∑t=1T​(rt​−rˉ)∑t=l+1T​(rt​−rˉ)(rt−l​−rˉ)​

The rˉ\bar{r}rˉ is the mean across the whole data.

This empirical estimation is called sample autocorrelation function. It plays an important role in linear series analysis.

White Noise

A time series rtr_trt​ is called a white noise if {rt}\{r_t\}{rt​} is a sequence of independent and identically distributed random variables with finite mean and variance. In particular, if rtr_trt​ is normally distributed with mean 0 and variance σ2\sigma^2σ2, the series is called a Gaussian white noise.

For white noise, all ACFs are zero.

Linear Time Series

A time series rtr_trt​ is said to be linear if

rt=μ+∑i=0∞ψiat−ir_t=\mu+\sum_{i=0}^\infty \psi_i a_{t-i}rt​=μ+i=0∑∞​ψi​at−i​

Where {at}\{a_t\}{at​} is a white noise sequence. And we define ψ0=1\psi_0=1ψ0​=1

For this model, we have

Therefore

ρl=yly0=∑i=0∞ψj+lψj1+∑i=1∞ψj2\rho_l=\frac{y_l}{y_0}=\frac{\sum_{i=0}^\infty\psi_{j+l}\psi_j}{1+\sum_{i=1}^\infty\psi_j^2}ρl​=y0​yl​​=1+∑i=1∞​ψj2​∑i=0∞​ψj+l​ψj​​

For weak stationary time series, the variance exist, and therefore we will have ρl→0,(l→∞)\rho_l\rightarrow0, (l\rightarrow\infty)ρl​→0,(l→∞).

AR

Consider a monthly return rtr_trt​, the lag-1 will be large and therefore rt−1r_{t-1}rt−1​ might be useful in predicting rtr_trt​. The simple model for this is:

rt=ϕ0+ϕ1rt−1+atr_t=\phi_0+\phi_1 r_{t-1}+a_trt​=ϕ0​+ϕ1​rt−1​+at​

The model is in the same form as linear regression, therefore we call is autoregressive model of order 1, or simply AR(1). There are also lots of similarity and difference between AR and linear regression, which we will talk about later. For now, we have

E(rt∣rt−1)=ϕ0+ϕ1rt−1,Var(rt∣rt−1)=σa2E(r_t|r_{t-1})=\phi_0+\phi_1r_{t-1}, Var(r_t|r_{t-1})=\sigma_a^2E(rt​∣rt−1​)=ϕ0​+ϕ1​rt−1​,Var(rt​∣rt−1​)=σa2​

This is Markov property. And there will be AR(p) which is

rt=ϕ0+ϕ1rt−1+⋯+ϕprt−p+atr_t=\phi_0+\phi_1 r_{t-1}+\dots +\phi_pr_{t-p} + a_trt​=ϕ0​+ϕ1​rt−1​+⋯+ϕp​rt−p​+at​

From stationary, we will have

And therefore

Therefore

γl={ϕ1γ1+σa2, if l=0ϕ1γl−1, otherwise\gamma_l = \left\{\begin{array} {l} \phi_1\gamma_{1}+\sigma_a^2,\ if\ l=0\\ \phi_1\gamma_{l-1},\ otherwise\\ \end{array}\right.γl​={ϕ1​γ1​+σa2​, if l=0ϕ1​γl−1​, otherwise​

And also from stationary

γ0=ϕ12γ0+σa2\gamma_0=\phi_1^2\gamma_0+\sigma_a^2γ0​=ϕ12​γ0​+σa2​

We could have

ρl=ϕ1ρl−1=ϕ1lρ0=ϕ1l\rho_l=\phi_1\rho_{l-1}=\phi_1^l\rho_0=\phi_1^lρl​=ϕ1​ρl−1​=ϕ1l​ρ0​=ϕ1l​

ρl=ϕ1ρl−1+ϕ2ρl−2+⋯+ϕpρl−p\rho_l=\phi_1\rho_{l-1}+\phi_2\rho_{l-2}+\dots+\phi_p\rho_{l-p}ρl​=ϕ1​ρl−1​+ϕ2​ρl−2​+⋯+ϕp​ρl−p​

How to identify AR model

There are two general methods to identify the p of AR model.

  • Partial Autocorrelation Function (ACF)

PACF of a stationary time series is a function of its ACF and is a useful tool for determining the order ppp of an AR model.

Consider the following AR models:

rr=ϕ0,1+ϕ1,1rt−1+e1t,rr=ϕ0,2+ϕ1,2rt−1+ϕ2,2rt−2+e1t,rr=ϕ0,3+ϕ1,3rt−1+ϕ2,3rt−2+ϕ3,3rt−3+e1t,⋮\begin{aligned} r_r&=\phi_{0,1}+\phi_{1,1}r_{t-1}+e_{1t},\\ r_r&=\phi_{0,2}+\phi_{1,2}r_{t-1}+\phi_{2,2}r_{t-2}+e_{1t},\\ r_r&=\phi_{0,3}+\phi_{1,3}r_{t-1}+\phi_{2,3}r_{t-2}+\phi_{3,3}r_{t-3}+e_{1t},\\ &\vdots \end{aligned}rr​rr​rr​​=ϕ0,1​+ϕ1,1​rt−1​+e1t​,=ϕ0,2​+ϕ1,2​rt−1​+ϕ2,2​rt−2​+e1t​,=ϕ0,3​+ϕ1,3​rt−1​+ϕ2,3​rt−2​+ϕ3,3​rt−3​+e1t​,⋮​

These models are in the form of a multi-dimension linear regression and can be estimated by the least-squares method. The estimated ϕ^1,1\hat{\phi}_{1,1}ϕ^​1,1​ is called the lag-1 sample PACF of rtr_trt​ and ϕ^2,2\hat{\phi}_{2,2}ϕ^​2,2​ is the lag-2 sample PACF and so on.

From the definition, the lag-p sample PACF shows the added contribution of rt−pr_{t-p}rt−p​ to an AR(p-1) model. Therefore, for an AR(p) model, the lag-p sample PACF should not be zero and the latter ones should be close to zero.

  • Information Criteria

There are several information based criteria available to determine the p. All of them are likelihood based, like Akaike information criterion(AIC).

Goodness of Fit

R2=1−residual sum of squarestotal sum of squaresR^2=1-\frac{residual\ sum\ of\ squares}{total\ sum\ of\ squares}R2=1−total sum of squaresresidual sum of squares​

For a stationary AR(p) model, the measure becomes

R2=1−∑t=p+1Ta^t2∑t=p+1T(rt−rˉt)2R^2=1-\frac{\sum_{t=p+1}^T\hat{a}_t^2}{\sum_{t=p+1}^T(r_t-\bar{r}_t)^2}R2=1−∑t=p+1T​(rt​−rˉt​)2∑t=p+1T​a^t2​​

For a given data set, it is well known that R2R^2R2 is a nondecreasing function of the number of parameters used. To overcome this weakness, we could use the adjusted R2R^2R2:

Radj2=1−σ^a2σ^r2R_{adj}^2=1-\frac{\hat{\sigma}_a^2}{\hat{\sigma}_r^2}Radj2​=1−σ^r2​σ^a2​​

MA

Think of a special case of AR

rt+θ1rt−1+θ12rt−2+⋯=ϕ0+atr_t+\theta_1r_{t-1}+\theta_1^2r_{t-2}+\dots=\phi_0+a_trt​+θ1​rt−1​+θ12​rt−2​+⋯=ϕ0​+at​

And since

rt−1+θ1rt−2+θ12rt−3+⋯=ϕ0+at−1r_{t-1}+\theta_1r_{t-2}+\theta_1^2r_{t-3}+\dots=\phi_0+a_{t-1}rt−1​+θ1​rt−2​+θ12​rt−3​+⋯=ϕ0​+at−1​

We have

rt=ϕ0(1−θ1)+at−θ1at−1r_t=\phi_0(1-\theta_1)+a_t-\theta_1a_{t-1}rt​=ϕ0​(1−θ1​)+at​−θ1​at−1​

Therefore, MA(1) is:

rt=c0+at−θ1at−1r_t=c_0+a_t-\theta_1a_{t-1}rt​=c0​+at​−θ1​at−1​

And MA(q) is

rt=c0+at−θ1at−1−...−θqat−qr_t=c_0+a_t-\theta_1a_{t-1}-...-\theta_qa_{t-q}rt​=c0​+at​−θ1​at−1​−...−θq​at−q​

rt−lrt=rt−lat−θ1rt−lat−1r_{t-l}r_t=r_{t-l}a_t-\theta_1r_{t-l}a_{t-1}rt−l​rt​=rt−l​at​−θ1​rt−l​at−1​

And

How to identify MA model

We could just use the property of ACF to identity qqq for MA.

ARMA

An ARMA model combines the idea of AR and MA into a compact form so that the number of parameters used is kept small. For the return series in finance the chance of using ARMA is low. However, it is highly relevant in volatility modeling. The simple ARMA(1, 1) is

rt−ϕ1rt−1=ϕ0+at−θ1at−1r_t-\phi_1r_{t-1}=\phi_0+a_t-\theta_1a_{t-1}rt​−ϕ1​rt−1​=ϕ0​+at​−θ1​at−1​

to make the function meaningful, we need ϕ1≠θ1\phi_1\neq\theta_1ϕ1​=θ1​

And the general form is

rt−ϕ1rt−1−⋯−ϕprt−p=ϕ0+at−θ1at−1−⋯−θqat−qr_t-\phi_1r_{t-1}-\dots-\phi_pr_{t-p}=\phi_0+a_t-\theta_1a_{t-1}-\dots-\theta_qa_{t-q}rt​−ϕ1​rt−1​−⋯−ϕp​rt−p​=ϕ0​+at​−θ1​at−1​−⋯−θq​at−q​

Properties

Here we only consider the properties for ARMA(1, 1)

From stationary, we have

μ−ϕ1μ=ϕ0\mu-\phi_1\mu=\phi_0\\μ−ϕ1​μ=ϕ0​

And assume ϕ0=0\phi_0=0ϕ0​=0 for simplicity, we have

Var(rt)=ϕ12Var(rt−12)+σa2+θ12σa2−2ϕ1θ1E(rt−1at−1)=ϕ12Var(rt−12)+(1−2ϕ1θ1+θ12)σa2\begin{aligned} Var(r_t)&=\phi_1^2Var(r_{t-1}^2)+\sigma_a^2+\theta_1^2\sigma_a^2-2\phi_1\theta_1E(r_{t-1}a_{t-1})\\ &=\phi_1^2Var(r_{t-1}^2)+(1-2\phi_1\theta_1+\theta_1^2)\sigma_a^2 \end{aligned}Var(rt​)​=ϕ12​Var(rt−12​)+σa2​+θ12​σa2​−2ϕ1​θ1​E(rt−1​at−1​)=ϕ12​Var(rt−12​)+(1−2ϕ1​θ1​+θ12​)σa2​​

And for ACF,

rtrt−l−ϕ1rt−1rt−l=atrt−l−θ1at−1rt−lr_tr_{t-l}-\phi_1r_{t-1}r_{t-l}=a_tr_{t-l}-\theta_1a_{t-1}r_{t-l}rt​rt−l​−ϕ1​rt−1​rt−l​=at​rt−l​−θ1​at−1​rt−l​

We have

γl={ϕ1γ0−θ1σa2, l=1ϕ1γl−1, l>1\gamma_l = \left\{\begin{array} {l} \phi_1\gamma_0-\theta_1\sigma_a^2,\ l=1\\ \phi_1\gamma_{l-1},\ l>1\\ \end{array}\right.γl​={ϕ1​γ0​−θ1​σa2​, l=1ϕ1​γl−1​, l>1​

And

ρl={ϕ1ρ0−θ1σa2γ0, l=1ϕ1ρl−1, l>1\rho_l = \left\{\begin{array} {l} \phi_1\rho_0-\frac{\theta_1\sigma_a^2}{\gamma_0},\ l=1\\ \phi_1\rho_{l-1},\ l>1\\ \end{array}\right.ρl​={ϕ1​ρ0​−γ0​θ1​σa2​​, l=1ϕ1​ρl−1​, l>1​

Thus, ACF of ARMA(1, 1) behaves very much like that of AR(1).

How to identify MA model

The ACF and PACF are not informative in determining the order of an ARMA model. There is something called extended autocorrelation function (EACF) to specify the order of an ARMA process.

Seasonal model

For seasonal data, there is often strong serial correlation. It is common to do seasonal differencing to it, which is

Δkxt=(1−Bk)xt=xt−xt−k\Delta_k x_t = (1-B^k)x_t=x_t-x_{t-k}Δk​xt​=(1−Bk)xt​=xt​−xt−k​

And some time, we need to do multiple differencing, which leads to

Δk(Δlxt)=(1−Bk)(1−Bl)xt\Delta_k(\Delta_lx_t)=(1-B^k)(1-B^l)x_tΔk​(Δl​xt​)=(1−Bk)(1−Bl)xt​

if

Zt=(1−B)dXt∼ARMA(p,q)Z_t=(1-B)^dX_t\sim ARMA(p, q)Zt​=(1−B)dXt​∼ARMA(p,q)

then XtX_tXt​ is ARIMA(p, d, q).
